message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Carbonic anhydrase helps catalyze the reaction between CO2 and H2O to form H2CO3, which then dissociates to H+ and HCO3-. Therefore, inhibition of erythrocyte carbonic anhydrase can significantly decrease CO2-carrying capacity of venous blood. The other options are not directly related to carbon dioxide-carrying capacity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The carbon dioxide-carrying capacity of blood is mainly due to the enzyme carbonic anhydrase, which catalyzes the interconversion of carbon dioxide and bicarbonate ions. Inhibition of carbonic anhydrase would decrease this capacity, leading to the symptoms described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Carbonic anhydrase is responsible for the formation of bicarbonate ions in red blood cells, which then carry carbon dioxide. Inhibition of carbonic anhydrase would decrease the ability of red blood cells to carry carbon dioxide, leading to decreased carbon dioxide-carrying capacity of the venous blood.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Carbonic anhydrase is an enzyme that helps convert carbon dioxide to bicarbonate in red blood cells. Inhibition of this enzyme will decrease the ability of red blood cells to transport carbon dioxide, leading to a decrease in the carbon dioxide-carrying capacity of venous blood. All other options do not directly affect the ability of red blood cells to carry carbon dioxide.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Carbonic anhydrase is an enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of carbon dioxide and water to bicarbonate and hydrogen ions. Inhibition of erythrocyte carbonic anhydrase would result in decreased carbon dioxide-carrying capacity of venous blood. The other options do not match the described mechanism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Carbonic anhydrase is an enzyme that catalyzes the reversible reaction of carbon dioxide into bicarbonate ions and protons. Inhibition of the enzyme will decrease the carbon dioxide-carrying capacity of the venous blood. All other options are not directly related to carbonic anhydrase.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Carbonic anhydrase is an enzyme that catalyzes the reversible reaction of carbon dioxide and water to carbonic acid in erythrocytes. Inhibition of this enzyme would decrease the ability of venous blood to carry carbon dioxide. None of the other options are related to carbonic anhydrase or would result in decreased carbon dioxide-carrying capacity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Carbonic anhydrase is an enzyme that catalyzes the interconversion of carbon dioxide and water to carbonic acid, which then dissociates into bicarbonate ions and hydrogen ions. Inhibition of erythrocyte carbonic anhydrase would result in decreased formation of bicarbonate ions, which would decrease the carbon dioxide-carrying capacity of the venous blood. None of the other options directly involve carbonic anhydrase.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Carbonic anhydrase catalyzes the reaction of carbon dioxide and water to form bicarbonate ions, which is important in the transportation of carbon dioxide in the blood. Inhibition of erythrocyte carbonic anhydrase would therefore decrease the carbon dioxide-carrying capacity of the venous blood. The other options are not directly related to the role of carbonic anhydrase in carbon dioxide transport.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Carbonic anhydrase is an enzyme that catalyzes the reversible reaction between carbon dioxide and water to form carbonic acid, which dissociates into hydrogen ions and bicarbonate ions. Inhibition of erythrocyte carbonic anhydrase will decrease the ability of red blood cells to transport carbon dioxide, leading to a decrease in the carbon dioxide-carrying capacity of the venous blood.
